Friday, June 15, 2007























FDA advisers reject Sanofi-Aventis weight-loss drug
Federal health advisers unanimously rejected the weight-loss drug rimonabant this week, voting 14-0 that the manufacturer, Sanofi-Aventis SA, had failed to prove that it is safe. A Food and Drug Administration medical officer had told the panel that the drug increases the risk of suicidal thoughts and other psychiatric problems. The FDA usually follows the advice of its advisory panels but is not required to do so. It's decision is expected by July 27.
FULL STORY




















Study: Race disparity in medical care persists
Black people were far less likely than whites to get specialized care after a heart attack and were more likely to die within a year,  says a study showing persistent racial disparities in medical care.
FULL STORY






Vaccine-autism link claims get day in court
The first test of nine test cases alleging that autism was caused by common childhood vaccines began this week; a victory could pave the way for thousands of autistic children to receive compensation.
FULL STORY






Possible early ovarian cancer signs ID'd
For the first time, cancer experts are advising women of certain symptoms that might alert them to ovarian cancer, a medically infamous "silent killer" that is hard to spot early and is one of the deadliest cancers.
FULL STORY






CDC: Lyme disease cases in U.S. doubled since 1991
The number of cases of Lyme disease has doubled in the United States since 1991 and these numbers are probably underestimated, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says.
FULL STORY
